docs.lead_paragraph: Pharmaceutical companies including Switzerland's Novartis and Roche are among those developing a treatment for a specific type of lung cancer, a field that is now so crowded it may impact profits.

headline.main: Returns May Suffer as Drugmakers Compete in Crowded Cancer Field
headline.print_headline: Returns May Suffer as Drugmakers Compete in Crowded Cancer Field

docs.snippet: Pharmaceutical companies including Switzerland's Novartis and Roche are among those developing a treatment for a specific type of lung cancer, a field that is now so crowded it may impact profits.

docs.lead_paragraph: “Lifestyle” programs, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, resulted in no net savings, a RAND study says.

headline.main: Study Raises Questions for Employer Wellness Programs
headline.print_headline: Study Raises Questions for Employer Health Efforts

docs.abstract: RAND Corp study says so-called lifestyle management programs offered by companies to their employees, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, result in no net cost savings; study examined more than 67,000 people eligible to participate in PepsiCo's wellness program.
docs.snippet: “Lifestyle” programs, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, resulted in no net savings, a RAND study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court heard arguments Monday on whether the state of Texas can enforce a law that led to the closing of several abortion clinics, a case that ultimately appears bound for the U.S. Supreme Court.

headline.main: Federal Appeals Court Reviews Texas Abortion Law
headline.print_headline: Federal Appeals Court Reviews Texas Abortion Law

docs.snippet: A federal appeals court heard arguments Monday on whether the state of Texas can enforce a law that led to the closing of several abortion clinics, a case that ultimately appears bound for the U.S. Supreme Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of medical marijuana, moving the state a step closer to policies embraced by advocates and lawmakers elsewhere.

headline.main: New York State Is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws
headline.print_headline: New York State Is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws

docs.abstract: New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo plans to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of marijuana by those with serious illnesses; shift by Cuomo comes as other states are taking increasingly liberal positions on the issue.
docs.snippet: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of medical marijuana, moving the state a step closer to policies embraced by advocates and lawmakers elsewhere.

byline.original: By SUSANNE CRAIG and JESSE McKINLEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Four tips for keeping New Year’s resolutions, inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health.
docs.abstract: Gray Matter column by Profs Katherine L Milkman and Kevin G Volpp offers four tips inspired by research on behavioral economics and health that will improve one's chances of keeping one's New Year's resolutions.
docs.snippet: Four tips for keeping New Year’s resolutions, inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health.

byline.original: By KATHERINE L. MILKMAN and KEVIN G. VOLPP

docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said the requirements for birth control coverage did not impose a “substantial burden” on an order of Roman Catholic nuns who challenged them.

headline.main: Justices Are Asked to Reject Nuns’ Challenge to Health Law
headline.print_headline: Justices Are Asked to Reject Nuns’ Challenge to Health Law

docs.abstract: Obama administration urges Supreme Court to reject lawsuit filed by the Little Sisters of the Poor, order of Roman Catholic nuns challenging requirements for many employers to provide health insurance coverage for birth control or face penalties under new health care law; Justice Dept says requirements do not impose 'substantial burden' on nuns’ exercise of religion because they can 'opt out' of the obligation.
docs.snippet: The Justice Department said the requirements for birth control coverage did not impose a “substantial burden” on an order of Roman Catholic nuns who challenged them.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Indian athletes, with easy access to legal steroids and minimal support from their nation, lead the world in suspensions for performance-enhancing drug use.

headline.main: Banned Substances Claim an Outsize Role in Athletics in India
headline.print_headline: Banned Substances Claim an Outsize Role in Athletics in India

docs.abstract: Indian athletes, with easy access to legal steroids and limited knowledge about their consequences, lead the world in suspensions for performance-enhancing drug use; nearly 500 have tested positive for banned substances since 2009, when India’s National Anti-Doping Agency, known as NADA, became fully functional; reasons for use of banned substances include poverty and lack of equipment, proper training and nutrition.
docs.snippet: Indian athletes, with easy access to legal steroids and minimal support from their nation, lead the world in suspensions for performance-enhancing drug use.

docs.lead_paragraph: Greece assumes the presidency of the European Union Wednesday, starting 2014 with a promise by the government to pull the country out of a six-year recession, keep a balanced budget, and effectively end a financial crisis that rattled the euro.

headline.main: Greece: Numbers Improve, Problems Worsen in 2014
headline.print_headline: Greece: Numbers Improve, Problems Worsen in 2014

docs.snippet: Greece assumes the presidency of the European Union Wednesday, starting 2014 with a promise by the government to pull the country out of a six-year recession, keep a balanced budget, and effectively end a financial crisis that rattled the euro.

docs.lead_paragraph: Justice Sonia Sotomayor is giving the government until Friday morning to respond to her decision on President Obama’s health care law.

headline.main: Justice Blocks Contraception Mandate on Insurance in Suit by Nuns
headline.print_headline: Justice Blocks Contraception Mandate on Insurance in Suit by Nuns

docs.abstract: Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor temporarily blocks the Obama administration from forcing some religious-affiliated groups to provide health insurance coverage of birth control or face penalties as part of the Affordable Care Act; acting at the request of an order of nuns in Colorado, Justice Sotomayor issues the stay just hours before the requirement was to go into effect.
docs.snippet: Justice Sonia Sotomayor is giving the government until Friday morning to respond to her decision on President Obama’s health care law.
